message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Epidemics on multilayer simplicial complexes
Paper Abstract: Simplicial complexes describe the simple fact that in social networks a link can connect more than two individuals. As we show here, this has far-reaching consequences for epidemic spreading, in particular in the context of a multilayer network model, where one layer is a virtual social network and the other one is a physical contact network. The social network layer is responsible for the transmission of information via pairwise or higher order 2-simplex interactions among individuals, while the physical layer is responsible for the epidemic spreading. We use the microscopic Markov chain approach to derive the probability transition equations and to determine epidemic outbreak thresholds. We further support these results with Monte Carlo simulations, which are in good agreement, thus confirming the analytical tractability of the proposed model. We find that information transmission rates are frequently low when actual disease transmission rates in the physical network are low or medium, and we show that this can be mitigated effectively by introducing 2-simplex interactions in the social network. The relative ease of introducing higher-order interactions in virtual social networks means that this could be exploited to inhibit epidemic outbreaks.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Simplicial complex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simplicial_complex"},{"title":"Link (simplicial complex) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Link_(simplicial_complex)"},{"title":"Abstract simplicial complex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstract_simplicial_complex"},{"title":"Simplicial complex recognition problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simplicial_complex_recognition_problem"},{"title":"Subdivision (simplicial complex) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subdivision_(simplicial_complex)"},{"title":"Simplicial homology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simplicial_homology"},{"title":"Simplicial map - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simplicial_map"},{"title":"Clique complex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clique_complex"},{"title":"Nerve complex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nerve_complex"},{"title":"Polyhedral complex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polyhedral_complex"}]

Here's what I found about simplicial complexes:

## Definition

A simplicial complex is a structured set of simplices (for example, points, line segments, triangles, and their n-dimensional counterparts) such that all the faces and intersections of the elements are also included in the set.

## Abstract Simplicial Complexes

In combinatorics, an abstract simplicial complex is a family of sets that is closed under taking subsets, and it is a purely combinatorial description of the geometric notion of a simplicial complex.(no content)For example, in a 2-dimensional simplicial complex, the sets in the family are the triangles (sets of size 3), their edges (sets of size 2), and their vertices (sets of size 1).

## Applications

Simplicial complexes have important applications in topology and data analysis. In algebraic topology, simplicial homology is the sequence of homology groups of a simplicial complex, which formalizes the idea of the number of holes of a given dimension in the complex.(no content)Because it is possible to compute the simplicial homology of a simplicial complex automatically and efficiently, simplicial homology has become important for application to real-life situations, such as image analysis, medical imaging, and data analysis in general.

Web search results for query: "Markov chain"

Links: [{"title":"Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain"},{"title":"Markov chain Monte Carlo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain_Monte_Carlo"},{"title":"Continuous-time Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous-time_Markov_chain"},{"title":"Discrete-time Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete-time_Markov_chain"},{"title":"Markov chain approximation method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain_approximation_method"},{"title":"Markov chain tree theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain_tree_theorem"},{"title":"Quantum Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_Markov_chain"},{"title":"Markov chain mixing time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain_mixing_time"},{"title":"Markov chain central limit theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain_central_limit_theorem"},{"title":"Markov Chains and Mixing Times - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_Chains_and_Mixing_Times"}]

## Overview

A Markov chain is a stochastic process describing a sequence of possible events in which the probability of each event depends only on the state attained in the previous event.(no content)In other words, "What happens next depends only on the state of affairs now."

## Types of Markov Chains

A discrete-time Markov chain (DTMC) is a countably infinite sequence in which the chain moves state at discrete time steps, while a continuous-time process is called a continuous-time Markov chain (CTMC).

## Key Characteristics

In a discrete-time Markov chain, the value of the next variable depends only on the value of the current variable, and not any variables in the past.(no content)A Markov chain can be described by a stochastic matrix, which lists the probabilities of moving to each state from any individual state.

## Applications

Markov chains have many applications as statistical models of real-world processes and provide the basis for general stochastic simulation methods known as Markov chain Monte Carlo, which are used for simulating sampling from complex probability distributions.

## Historical Background

Markov processes are named in honor of the Russian mathematician Andrey Markov.(no content)Andrey Markov studied Markov processes in the early 20th century, publishing his first paper on the topic in 1906.

Links: [{"title":"Direct simulation Monte Carlo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct_simulation_Monte_Carlo"},{"title":"Monte Carlo method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo_method"},{"title":"Monte Carlo methods in finance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo_methods_in_finance"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo_simulation_modelling_of_industrial_systems"},{"title":"Monte Carlo methods for electron transport - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo_methods_for_electron_transport"},{"title":"Multilevel Monte Carlo method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multilevel_Monte_Carlo_method"},{"title":"Subset simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subset_simulation"},{"title":"Carmonette - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carmonette"},{"title":"Poker calculator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poker_calculator"},{"title":"Category:Monte Carlo methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Monte_Carlo_methods"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Monte Carlo simulation:

## What is Monte Carlo Simulation?

Monte Carlo methods are a broad class of computational algorithms that rely on repeated random sampling to obtain numerical results.(no content)The underlying concept is to use randomness to solve problems that might be deterministic in principle.

## Origin of the Name

The name comes from the Monte Carlo Casino in Monaco, where the primary developer of the method, mathematician Stanisław Ulam, was inspired by his uncle's gambling habits.

## Primary Applications

Monte Carlo methods are mainly used in three distinct problem classes: optimization, numerical integration, and generating draws from a probability distribution. Additional applications include:

- Modeling phenomena with significant uncertainty in inputs, such as calculating the risk of a nuclear power plant failure
- Solving problems by directly simulating the underlying physical process and then calculating the average result of the process
- Simulating systems with many coupled degrees of freedom, such as fluids, disordered materials, strongly coupled solids, and cellular structures

## Historical Context

In the late 1940s, Stanisław Ulam invented the modern version of the Markov Chain Monte Carlo method while he was working on nuclear weapons projects at the Los Alamos National Laboratory.(no content)In the 1950s Monte Carlo methods were used at Los Alamos for the development of the hydrogen bomb, and became popularized in the fields of physics, physical chemistry, and operations research.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about multilayer networks:

## Overview

In network theory, multidimensional networks, a special type of multilayer network, are networks with multiple kinds of relations.

## Applications and Importance

Increasingly sophisticated attempts to model real-world systems as multilayer networks have yielded valuable insight in the fields of social network analysis, economics, urban and international transport, ecology, psychology, medicine, biology, commerce, climatology, physics, computational neuroscience, operations management, and finance.

## Key Characteristics

Real world networks often have added complexity in the form of multiple types of relations between system elements.(no content)There are as many layers as there are dimensions, and the links between nodes within each layer are simply all the links for a given dimension.

## Complexity and Analysis

An active field of research is devoted to simplify the structure of such systems by employing some kind of dimensionality reduction.

## Diffusion Processes

In multiplex networks, a special type of multilayer system, diffusion exhibits two regimes: 1) the weight of inter-layer links is not high enough and the multiplex system behaves like two (or more) uncoupled networks; 2) the weight of inter-layer links is high enough that layers are coupled each other, raising unexpected physical phenomena.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "epidemic model"

Links: [{"title":"Mathematical modelling of infectious diseases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_modelling_of_infectious_diseases"},{"title":"Compartmental models (epidemiology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compartmental_models_(epidemiology)"},{"title":"Reed–Frost model","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reed–Frost_model"},{"title":"Epidemic models on lattices - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemic_models_on_lattices"},{"title":"Rumor spread in social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rumor_spread_in_social_network"},{"title":"Epidemiological transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemiological_transition"},{"title":"Noah Mills - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noah_Mills"},{"title":"Kermack–McKendrick theory","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kermack–McKendrick_theory"},{"title":"Directed percolation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Directed_percolation"}]

Based on the web search results, here's a comprehensive overview of epidemic models:

## What is an Epidemic Model?

Epidemic modeling is a tool that has been used to study the mechanisms by which diseases spread, to predict the future course of an outbreak and to evaluate strategies to control an epidemic.(no content)Mathematical models can project how infectious diseases progress to show the likely outcome of an epidemic and help inform public health interventions, using basic assumptions or collected statistics along with mathematics to find parameters for various infectious diseases.

## Key Types of Epidemic Models

### Compartmental Models
Compartmental models are a mathematical framework used to simulate how populations move between different states or "compartments", in which the population is divided into compartments labeled with shorthand notation – most commonly S, I, and R, representing Susceptible, Infectious, and Recovered individuals.(no content)Epidemiologists use these models for analyzing disease transmission dynamics, projecting the total number of infections and recoveries over time, and estimating key epidemiological parameters such as the basic reproduction number (R0) or effective reproduction number (Rt).

### Historical Models
The Kermack–McKendrick epidemic model (1927) and the Reed–Frost epidemic model (1928) both describe the relationship between susceptible, infected and immune individuals in a population, with the Kermack–McKendrick epidemic model being successful in predicting the behavior of outbreaks very similar to that observed in many recorded epidemics.

### Modern Approaches
Recently, agent-based models (ABMs) have been used in exchange for simpler compartmental models, and epidemiological ABMs have been used to inform public health (nonpharmaceutical) interventions against the spread of SARS-CoV-2.

Links: [{"title":"Social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network"},{"title":"The Social Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Social_Network"},{"title":"Social networking service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_networking_service"},{"title":"List of social networking services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_social_networking_services"},{"title":"Social media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media"},{"title":"Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Distributed social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_social_network"},{"title":"The Social Reckoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Social_Reckoning"},{"title":"Social Networks (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Networks_(journal)"},{"title":"Threads (social network) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Threads_(social_network)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about social networks:

## Definition

A social network is a social structure consisting of a set of social actors (such as individuals or organizations), networks of dyadic ties, and other social interactions between actors.

## Social Networking Services

A social networking service is a type of online social media platform which people use to build social networks or social relationships with other people who share similar personal or career content, interests, activities, backgrounds or real-life connections.(no content)Social networking sites allow users to share ideas, digital photos and videos, posts, and to inform others about online or real-world activities and events with people within their social network.

## Historical Development

Social media started in the mid-1990s with the invention of platforms like GeoCities, Classmates.com, and SixDegrees.com. SixDegrees was unique as it was the first online service designed for people to connect using their actual names instead of anonymously.(no content)In the late 1990s, user profiles became a central feature of social networking sites, allowing users to compile lists of "friends" and search for other users with similar interests.

## Social Network Analysis

Social network analysis is the process of investigating social structures through the use of networks and graph theory. It characterizes networked structures in terms of nodes (individual actors, people, or things within the network) and the ties, edges, or links (relationships or interactions) that connect them.

## Current Usage

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media, some 59% of the global population.

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media, some 59% of the global population.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Epidemics on multilayer simplicial complexes". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Key Entities Identified (6 triples):**

1. **Simplicial complex** (concept) - PROPOSES: The paper proposes a novel model using simplicial complexes to represent higher-order interactions in multilayer networks.

2. **Multidimensional network** (concept) - PROPOSES: The paper proposes a multilayer network model combining virtual social networks and physical contact networks.

3. **Mathematical modelling of infectious diseases** (task) - USES: The paper applies epidemic modeling techniques to study disease spreading on multilayer simplicial complexes.

4. **Social network** (concept) - USES: The paper uses social networks as one layer of the multilayer model for information transmission.

5. **Markov chain** (method) - USES: The paper uses the microscopic Markov chain approach to derive probability transition equations for epidemic thresholds.

6. **Monte Carlo method** (method) - USES: The paper uses Monte Carlo simulations to validate the theoretical analytical results.

**Validation Status:** ✅ PASSED - All checks passed successfully!

The paper properly has at least 1 "proposes" relation (required for contribution papers) and 5 "uses" relations (required for all papers).

Sources:
- [Simplicial complex](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simplicial_complex)
- [Multidimensional network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multidimensional_network)
- [Mathematical modelling of infectious diseases](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_modelling_of_infectious_diseases)
- [Social network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network)
- [Markov chain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain)
- [Monte Carlo method](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo_method)
